content.question: A piece of <math alttext="F e solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed into <math alttext="H 2 O liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>l</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> at <math alttext="75 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>75</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in an insulated container. A student predicts that when thermal equilibrium is reached, the <math alttext="F e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms, being more massive than the <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules, will have a higher average kinetic energy than the <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules. Which of the following best explains why the student’s prediction is incorrect?

choices.label: At thermal equilibrium, the less massive <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules would have a higher average kinetic energy than the <math alttext="F e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms because they are more free to move than are the <math alttext="F e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms.

At thermal equilibrium, the collisions between the <math alttext="F e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms and the <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules would cease because the average kinetic energies of their particles would have become the same.

At thermal equilibrium, the movement of both the <math alttext="F e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms and the <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules would cease; thus, the average kinetic energy of their particles would have to be the same.

At thermal equilibrium, the average kinetic energy of the <math alttext="F e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms cannot be greater than that of the <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules; the average kinetic energies must be the same according to the definition of thermal equilibrium.

content.answer: At thermal equilibrium, the average kinetic energy of the <math alttext="F e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms cannot be greater than that of the <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules; the average kinetic energies must be the same according to the definition of thermal equilibrium.

skill.text: 6.E: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using connections between particulate and macroscopic scales or levels.
